Environmental, Health and Safety Policy

The Birchwood Power Facility is committed to achieving environmental, health & safety excellence.  This is the responsibility of both the management and employees in all functions.  Our facility strives to provide a safe and healthy working environment and to avoid adverse impact to the environment and the communities in which we do business.  Our programs combine clear leadership by management, the participation of all employees and functions.
 
At our facility, we are accomplishing these goals through the implementation of the Birchwood Power Facility Environmental, Health & Safety Procedures.  These procedures ensure: 

A?    That facilities have a clear statement of the environmental, health & safety policies. 
    
A?    Safe and healthy working environments for all employees, as well as contractors, consistent with regulatory requirements and best management practices.
    
A?    Established procedures to recognize, evaluate and control environmental, health & safety hazards at the facility. 
    
A?    Appropriate levels of environmental, health & safety training for all employees.  
    
A?    Both management and employee involvement in environmental, health and safety.  
    
A?    Defined responsibilities, accountability and disciplinary actions.   
    
A?    Continuous evaluation and update of the environmental, health and safety programs to ensure continued improvement and lasting effectiveness.

At our facility, we realize that our most valued assets are our employees and their safety is of utmost importance to the business.  Both management and employees will consider themselves a team working together to accomplish the common goal of a safe, healthy and environmentally compliant workplace.  

Facility and regulated substances 
 
Birchwood Power Facility is a 262 MW (gross) pulverized coal-fired electrical generation power plant. The facility operates using a state-of-the-art air emission control system that includes a  Selective Catalytic Reduction

System (SCR) to control oxides of nitrogen. Anhydrous ammonia,  an RMP regulated substance, is an essential element used to convert oxides of nitrogen to elemental nitrogen. The part of the system subject to the RMP regulations is the ammonia storage and dilution system.  
 
General accidental release prevention program 

 
The accidental release prevention program at the Birchwood Power Facility is focused on the safe management of ammonia used in the ammonia storage and dilution system.  The first step in the prevention program is the establishment of a management system to assign overall responsibility and responsibility for the individual program elements. Additional steps include: ensuring process safety information on the ammonia storage and dilution system is accurate, complete and up-to-date; ensuring the system is designed and modified safely by periodically conducting process hazard analyses; ensuring the system is operated and maintained in a safe manner by developing, maintaining and implementing Standard Operating and Preventive Maintenance Procedures; ensuring Plant employee are adequately trained and tested in the RMP program elements; ensuring new equipment and modifications to the ammonia storage and dilution system are designed, constructed, operated and maintained by following facility-wide Management of Change Procedures, and observing Pre-startup Review and Hot Work Permit Procedures; ensuring contractors are qualified, and oriented to the site hazards; and conducting periodic Compliance Audits and Incident Investigations including resolution of recommendations made during these investigations/reviews.
  
The RMP is also written to meet the OSHA Process Safety Management requirements. The ammonia storage tank, vapor system and dilution skip are designed and constructed to meet or exceed all applicable engineering standards and equipped to minimize the possibility of a release of ammonia. For example the ammonia tank is constructed with excess f

low control valves designed to instantaneously stop a release of ammonia resulting from a tank piping failure and a water sprinkler system that would engage if the tank pressure goes above a predetermined set point. Ammonia flow to the dilution skid can be remotely shut off in the event of a pipe leak. The dilution skid is equipped with an ammonia monitor that automatically alarms if ammonia leaks into the boiler room.

 
The ammonia tank and dilution skip is maintained under an electronic preventative maintenance program that includes regular inspection of equipment and testing of critical components.
 
The facility provides training to new employees and refresher training to all employees.
 
Five-year accident history 

There have been no ammonia releases since startup of the facility in 1996.
 
Emergency response program 
 
The facility has implemented a comprehensive Emergency Action Plan which is used to respond to all anticipated emergencies. The plan covers the actions to be taken in the event of a personal injury, fire, natural disaster, civil disobedience,  and/or a release of petroleum products or chemicals including ammonia. Topics coved by the plan include evacuation procedures; recognizing emergencies; emergency action procedures; employee coordination; notifying local emergency and medical response agencies so that they can notify the public as needed; emergency response contacts; emergency response equipment; government agency notification; incident investigation and corrective action procedures; emergency alarm system; annual emergency action training and  quarterly emergency drills; and pre-emergency coordination with the LEPC. 
 
The Birchwood Power Facility is included in the King George County Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC) emergency response plan and actively participates in the LEPC.  
 
Planned changes to improve safety 
 
The Birchwood Power Facility is currently considering the install an ammonia tank enclosure system including am
monia-monitoring equipment and/or fogging system that would automatically activate in the event of an ammonia leak.
